meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried
meeting_annotations.transcript: fact that that a computer can predict a structure at all for so much of the proteome. I was almost wondering for the people who work in this field, were they surprised? Because the algorithms that people typically use predict disorder like Disopred and IUPred, they'll give you these numbers like oh like 70, 80% of the human proteome is disordered. It's like well if that's true then how come a computer can predict structures for like 50% of the proteome and like 90% of like the E. coli proteome. So like to me, I thought that was like very much inconsistent with sort of like the view that like Julie Forman-Kay has been proposing that like this is just as common in bacteria as it is in eukaryotes. Like I don't think they can possibly be consistent with like what we know about how structured proteomes really are. So. I don't want to be too controversial but that's just been something I've been thinking a lot about.
meeting_annotations.other: He uses hand gestures to emphasize his points and seems very engaged in the topic.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Allie Obermeyer
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah, my impression was that the bacterial proteome was much less disordered than the eukaryotic proteome. And and I guess there's certainly a lot of disordered domains within even proteins that do have a structured fold predicted by AlphaFold, right? So.
meeting_annotations.other: She nods in agreement before starting to speak.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Stephen Fried
meeting_annotations.transcript: And then AlphaFold just kind of makes it like little spaghetti, but yeah.
meeting_annotations.other: He uses a hand gesture to mimic "spaghetti".

meeting_annotations.speaker: Masha Kamenetska
meeting_annotations.transcript: Has anyone tried just putting I don't know, doing basically microrheology, so putting like getting nanoparticles inside a cell and then by seeing tracking them move, you can tell something about the local, you know, viscoelastic properties of the local environment. So you can see how much heterogeneity there is in a cell. Have people done something like that? It would seems like a pretty straightforward. Or would that be valuable I don't know.
meeting_annotations.other: She uses hand gestures to illustrate her idea of tracking particles.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Lars Plate
meeting_annotations.transcript: I think people have used fluorescent dyes to do this and just look at yeah, polarization based based assays. And so there's like environmentally sensitive dyes. So Shin Zhang who I think has been in the Scialog before, like he's designing some of these and tagging proteins with this to kind of track track things.

meeting_annotations.speaker: Cathy Murphy
meeting_annotations.transcript: Yeah I don't I it seems that sounds familiar to me Masha so I guess it it kind of has been done. The more common thing would be to have like a bunch of cells in a matrix and then the cells are moving in the matrix and you got some kind of beads in there and you can look at the displacement of the beads and then infer how the cell is moving
